item.title: Process Scheduling and Context Switching: How Operating Systems Share the CPU
item.description: A single CPU core can only execute one instruction stream at a time, yet modern systems run hundreds of processes simultaneously. This illusion of parallelism requires the operating system to rapidly switch between processes, giving each a slice of CPU time. The scheduler—the component that decides who runs next—profoundly affects system responsiveness, throughput, and fairness. Understanding scheduling reveals why your interactive applications feel smooth or sluggish and why some workloads perform better than others.
